Procedure Type: Creation of Shunt from brain to blood vessels
Treatment Reason:
When the procedure is needed: 
hydrocephalus (when there's too much fluid in the brain)
Brain tumors that can block CSF flow
Traumatic brain injury that blocks CSF flow

When should the procedure not be done: 
active infection
severe bleeding disorders
inadequate cerebral perfusion (poor brain blood flow)
Previous shunt infections
Presence of obstructions that block fluid flow in the brain
Surgeon's Action: The procedure will be about an hour long. The surgeon creates a small tube, called a shunt, that connects the brain to blood vessels in the neck or heart to drain excess fluid. This procedure is done to treat conditions like hydrocephalus, where fluid builds up in the brain and causes swelling. The surgeon may use a tiny camera, called an endoscope, to help guide the procedure.
Pre-surgery Facts:
Make sure to inform your healthcare providers about all the medications and supplements you're using. Avoid drinking alcohol prior to your surgery, and if you smoke, stopping a few days before your surgery can greatly reduce the risk of breathing problems during your surgery.

Be sure to follow your provider's instructions for taking the following: aspirin, vitamin E, multivitamins, herbal remedies, other dietary supplements, and NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen (Advil® and Motrin®) and naproxen (Aleve®).

Stop eating at midnight (12 a.m.) the night before your surgery. This includes hard candy and gum.If your healthcare provider told you to stop eating earlier than midnight, follow their instructions. Some people need to fast (not eat) for longer before their surgery.
Medications: Be sure to tell your physician or surgeon all medications you are currently taking, as well as any vitamins, supplements, or other substances you are taking.
Day Before Surgery:
Note the time of your surgery and where to go

Follow your provider's instructions for eating prior to surgery - typically you should stop eating at midnight (12 am) the night before your surgery, and this includes hard candy and gum.

What to bring:
Your breathing device for sleep apnea (such as your CPAP machine), if you have one, Your incentive spirometer, if you have one, Any forms/documents you may need depending on your hospital, Your cell phone and charger, A case for your personal items, if you have any. Eyeglasses, hearing aids, dentures, prosthetic devices, wigs, and religious articles are examples of personal items."
Morning of Surgery:
From midnight (12 a.m.) until 2 hours before your scheduled arrival time, you should only drink the liquids listed below. Avoid eating or drinking anything not included on this list. Stop drinking entirely 2 hours before your arrival time.
Water, Clear apple juice, clear grape juice, or clear cranberry juice, Gatorade or Powerade, Black coffee or plain tea. 

If you have diabetes, please be mindful of the sugar content in these drinks. To help manage your blood sugar levels, consider choosing sugar-free, low-sugar, or no-added-sugar options.

Staying hydrated before surgery is important, so feel free to drink if you’re thirsty. However, avoid drinking more than necessary, as you will receive intravenous (IV) fluids during your procedure.

Take your medicines as instructed.

Shower and wash your hair with baby shampoo the morning of your surgery. Do not use conditioner or hair products such as hair spray or hair gel. Do not put on any lotion, cream, deodorant, makeup, powder, perfume, or cologne after your shower.

Choose comfortable, loose-fitting clothing for the day of your surgery.

If you normally wear contact lenses, please opt for glasses instead, as wearing contacts during surgery can harm your eyes.

Avoid wearing any metal objects and remove all jewelry, including body piercings.

When it’s time for your surgery, you will need to remove items such as eyeglasses, hearing aids, dentures, prosthetic devices, wigs, and religious articles. You will either walk into the operating room or be transported there on a stretcher by a staff member. Once there, a member of the operating room team will assist you onto the operating bed and place compression boots on your lower legs. These boots gently inflate and deflate to promote healthy blood flow in your legs. After you’re settled, your anesthesiologist will administer anesthesia through your IV line, allowing you to fall asleep. You will also receive fluids through your IV during and after the procedure.
Right After Surgery: You'll feel like you just fell asleep. After your surgery, you'll wake up within a few minutes to a few hours, and a nurse will keep track of your temperature, pulse, blood pressure, and oxygen levels. Don't wait until you are in severe pain...You may get oxygen through a tube resting below your nose and mouth, pain medicine, and compression boots on your lower legs. You may be in your hospital's post-anesthesia care unit for a few hours or overnight. Most people stay in the hospital for 1-2 days.
Day of Discharge: You may experience mild headaches or discomfort after your surgery. Be sure to talk to your provider about any symptoms you may be experiencing, and you'll get a prescription for pain medicine before you leave the hospital. Talk with your healthcare provider about any concerns you may have.
Post-surgery What to expect:
Your first appointment after your surgery will typically be 7 to 10 days after your surgery. You may experience some pain after your surgery, which you may have been prescribed pain medicine for. Be sure to take your medications as directed and needed. 

It’s common for the skin below your incision to feel numb. This happens because some of your nerves were cut during your surgery. The numbness will go away over time.

Keep your incisions clean and dry for 5 days after your surgery. 
Don’t shower for 5 days after your surgery. 
Avoid baths, hot tubs, and swimming pools until your doctor tells you it’s OK.
Don’t use a hair dryer, creams, ointment, or hair products on your incisions until they’re completely healed. This takes about 6 weeks.
Post-surgery Common symptoms not to be w:
If you notice any symptoms you’re unsure about or that are uncomfortable, don’t hesitate to reach out to your doctor.

It’s common to have mild headaches or some tenderness around the incision in the first few days after surgery. You might also feel some soreness, tightness, or muscle discomfort around the incision for several months. Your doctor can help you manage any discomfort. Additionally, certain medications, like opioids, may cause constipation, so keep your doctor informed for the best support.
Post-surgery adverse signs/symptoms:
The skin around your incision is very red or getting more red.
The skin around your incision is warmer than usual.
The area around your incision is starting to swell or getting more swollen.
You see drainage that looks like pus (thick and milky).
Your incision smells bad.
Post-surgery nutrition: You will be able to eat all the foods you were able to eat prior to your surgery. Eating a balanced diet with high calories and protein can help you heal after a surgery, and be sure to drink plenty of liquids. Try to drink 8-10 oz of liquids every day, try to choose liquids without alcohol and limit caffeine. If you have any further questions or want to learn more, be sure to ask your doctor or ask to see a clinical dietitian nutritionist.
Post-surgery physical activity:
For the first 4 to 6 weeks after your surgery:

Avoid lifting anything heavier than 10 pounds (4.5 kilograms).
Refrain from high-intensity activities like jogging and playing tennis.
Do not engage in contact sports, such as football.
Low-impact activities like walking and climbing stairs can help you regain strength and improve your well-being. Aim for 20 to 30 minutes of physical activity at least 2 to 3 times daily. You could walk outside or even at a local mall or shopping center.

It’s normal to feel more tired than usual after surgery, and recovery varies from person to person. Try to increase your activity level gradually, but make sure to rest between sessions. Rest is essential for your recovery.

Surgeon's Action: The surgeon removes the upper part of the uterus leaving the cervix in place (supracervical/subtotal/partial hysterectomy), entire uterus including the cervix (total hysterectomy), or the uterus with fallopian tubes and ovaries via vaginal, abdominal, or laproscopic technique. This procedure is performed due to uterine fibroids, endometriosis, pelvic support problems like uterine prolapse, abnormal uterine bleeding, cancer, and/or chronic pelvic pain, and to prevent further complications.
The surgeon performs a cesarean section (or C section) to remove the fetus from the uterus.

The surgeon removes the gallbladder, a small organ located under the liver that stores bile, via laproscopic technique or larger incision (open cholecystectomy). This procedure is performed due to gallbladder infection (cholecystitis) or chronic pain due to gallstones, and to prevent further complications.

The surgeon removes an inflamed appendix, a saclike structure situated in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen at the junction of the large and small intestines. This procedure is performed to relieve pain, due evidence of active inflammation or scarring from previous inflammation, rupture, or to prevent rupture. This procedure may be done via open or minimally invasive laproscopic technique.

The surgeon reduces stomach volume (gastric restriction) by vertically dividing and removing 85% of the stomach, with the remaining stomach resembling a tube or sleeve. This procedure is performed to generate weight loss by reducing stomach volume to 1-5 ounces.

The surgeon reduces stomach volume by creating a stomach pouch that can hold approximately 1 ounce of food and attaching it to a section of the small intestine called the Roux limb. The stomach pouch will expand to hold 4-6 ouces over time. This procedure is performed to reduce the amount of food eaten and absorbed, rate of food emptying and increase the feeling of fullness, resulting in weight loss.

The surgeon reduces stomach volume by creating a smaller stomach resembling a tube or sleeve. A loop of small intestine is connected directly to the stomach and the latter portion of the rest of the small intestine, bypassing the portion of the small intestine that carries the digestive (bile and pancreatic) juices. This procedure is performed to generate and maintain long-term weight loss.

The surgeon removes damaged cartilage and bone from the knee and replaces it with an artifical joint or prosthesis. This procedure is performed when diseased or worn down cartilage or bone is present, due to conditions such as osteoarthritis, ostenecrosis, rheumatoid arthritis, fractures, etc.

The surgeon removes the arthritic ball of the femur (thigh bone) and damaged cartilage and bone from the hip socket and replaces it with an artificial ball and socket joint. This procedure is performed when arthritic, diseased or worn down cartilage or bone is present due to osteoarthritis. This procedure may be performed via open or minimally invasive technique.

The surgeon uses metal devices such as rods, pins, screws or plates to stablize and restore the bones to their original positions in the hip after a fracture. Bone grafting may also be performed to help heal the fracture.
